title: 109_hr5554
content: The Workplace Safety and Health Transparency Act of 2006 is cited as the short title. The Occupational Health and Safety Act of 1970 is amended to include the adoption of nongovernmental standards by OSHA. The Workplace Safety and Health Transparency Act of 2006 amends the Occupational Health and Safety Act of 1970 to restrict the Secretary from incorporating any findings or standards from organizations unless certain criteria are met. The Workplace Safety and Health Transparency Act of 2006 amends the Occupational Health and Safety Act of 1970 to require the Secretary to investigate and identify any findings, guidelines, or standards not compliant with specified requirements within 180 days of enactment. Results must be published in the Federal Register and considered final, subject to court review. The Workplace Safety and Health Transparency Act of 2006 amends the Occupational Health and Safety Act of 1970 to require the Secretary to investigate and identify non-compliant findings, guidelines, or standards within 180 days. The Secretary's actions are subject to court review. Additionally, State plans cannot be approved if they reference non-compliant standards from any organization. The Workplace Safety and Health Transparency Act of 2006 amends the Occupational Health and Safety Act of 1970 to require nationally recognized standards to be adopted through a consensus process that considers diverse views. SEC. 3. Adoption of nongovernmental standards under the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act. Section 101 of the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 is amended to require the Secretary to not adopt any findings, guidelines, standards, rules, or regulations from any organization unless certain criteria are met. The Secretary must designate standards after consultation with Federal agencies, publish findings in the Federal Register, subject to review by a District Court. For rulemaking proceedings initiated by the Secretary before enactment, investigate and identify non-compliant findings, guidelines, or recommendations within 180 days. Results of investigations must be published. The Secretary must publish investigation results in the Federal Register and ensure that any final rules or standards do not rely on non-compliant findings or recommendations. Actions taken by the Secretary are subject to review by a United States district court.
